text: Your protagonist should be an everyman, which is to say exactly like you but with better romantic prospects.
It's about time for a thinly veiled metaphor for that really unfair fight you had with your girlfriend last week.
If a character is in New York, she’s got to be either a model or a writer, right?
If your alien culture isn’t a thinly veiled allegory for contemporary politics, what’s the point?
If you pay attention to racial representation in your work, it probably means you're secretly racist. Better just make everyone white.
Why would you need a dictionary? You've already got a thesaurus!
Throes.
Just stick "gate" on the end. That's basically what Woodward and Bernstein did.
Is that character's name overtly symbolic? No? Might as well scrap the whole book.
Why would your book need to speak for itself when you'll be around to explain it to the Amazon commenters?
You don't need to hire a designer for that cover! Just use a bunch of left-justified Helvetica or something.
If you make that kid the Chosen Hero, you can totally bypass any other character development!

Submission guidelines are for suckers. Live free or die.
Look, if that estranged parent isn't going to be a chosen hero or major villain, you might as well just kill them off right now.
Video game technology basically plateaued at the Super Nintendo, right?
Oh, you don't really need to run that transliterated slang by a native speaker. I'm sure you're using it correctly.
Yes. Those wolves would definitely spontaneously befriend your protagonist. That sounds like exactly the sort of thing wolves would do.
An evil twin? Sure, go for it!
Love at first sight is the only true love.
A seasoned warrior wearing plate armor that protects none of her vital organs or major blood vessels.

Have your hero break into their love interest's room while the love interest is sleeping would be SUPER romantic.
Yes, that doctor is definitely qualified to perform complex surgery, regardless their specialty. Totally believable. Run with it.
Yes. That is EXACTLY how quantum physics works. Well done.
What if your narrator WERE the killer?!
Your protagonist is just a little too perfect? Maybe consider making her adorably clumsy and in need of frequent rescue.
Awkward blind dates.

The world can never have too many Bukowski knock-offs.

Two guys trying to get laid.
A successful businessman learning how to love and maybe also, like, dance or something.
Acrostics.

TWIST: What if the robots overcame their programming and TRIED TO OVERTHROW THE HUMANS?
It doesn't matter if your epigrams are relevant or coherent if they're in another language!
Have you considered adding a creepy kid who's too smart for their age?
Just change the names. No one in your hometown will ever figure out that your novel is actually about them.
Graphic violence? Ooh, you're really pushing the envelope there. How mature and edgy of you!
Song lyrics.
You never know what the latest trend will be, so make sure to include every single type of supernatural creature you have ever heard of.
Common nouns are the new proper names.
You don't need an editor! You don't need anyone!
Quality is inversely proportional to accessibility. If people like your book, you've done something terribly wrong.
When you introduce a new female supporting character, take a moment to clarify whether your protagonist would "tap that."
Don't listen to those critics: all that really matters are your intentions.
Yes. "Fisting" is absolutely an appropriate word to describe *any* activity involving a fist.
You're right. Your friends' inside jokes will DEFINITELY go over great with a larger audience.
No, you're not writing yourself into a corner by making your protagonist an award-winning poet. How hard can it be to fudge a sonnet?
It's not a Dances With Wolves ripoff if it's set on a distant planet.
Pourquoi débourser pour un pro quand Google Translate est gratuit? Ce n'est pas comme anyone'll connaître la différence.
Existential crises of the extremely wealthy.
Don't think of it as a novel. Think of it as a chance to retroactively win every argument you have ever walked away from.
Build sympathy for characters by having their relatives and peers harass and ostracize them for exaggeratedly petty reasons.
Vampires, but maybe, like, they feel bad about it?
Men and women, amirite?
Commit to a motif: everything is conspiracy, or everything is coincidence.
Have another drink.
Africa's basically one really big country, right?
Nothing's edgier than casual misogyny.
For historical verisimilitude, replace every "you" with "thee" or "thou."
It's not really an exposition dump if a character is reading it off a futuristic device.
What if the main character were--get this--A WRITER?
Men are square-jawed ciphers. Save your adjectives for women and favorite guns.
Now is the perfect point in the story for a 2000-word ideological manifesto from your thinly-veiled fictional stand-in.
You're right: A sanitized Medieval France where everyone's white and uses modern idioms is a very original setting. Go for it.

Movie references are the new speech patterns.
Make it grittier.
Go ahead. Spell out that accent phonetically.
There's no better way to emphasize the tragedy of a young woman's untimely death than lovingly describing how hot her corpse is.
Plucky orphans.
What is this, the school bus? If you're old enough to write sex scenes, you're old enough to use exclusively scientific terms for genitalia.

For additional verisimilitude, make sure to list the brand and model of every item your characters encounter.
You don't want readers to solve the crime ahead of your detective--better withhold all the really critical clues.
Remember: one culture per alien planet. More than that, and you're just showing off.
A lot goes down in that chapter. You should probably add a spoiler warning.
A Yoruba folktale, but the twist is that all the characters are white and live in Williamsburg.
Comics are the new screenplays!
If it's based on a true story, you don't need to worry about whether it's believable.
You're right. Naming and describing every combo move in that fight scene will make it much more exciting.
Make good use of that expensive degree by having characters discuss your esoteric field of study as often and technically as possible!
Pretty people with terminal illnesses.

With more Benzedrine and casual racism, you could be the next Kerouac!
The only thing more important than the color of your protagonist's eyes is their signature catchphrase.
If the rights to your favorite character haven't entered the public domain, it's because you didn't believe hard enough.
"Exotic" is such a versatile adjective! Use it as often as possible.
Seriously, though: Vampires.
Yes, a graphic rape is DEFINITELY what your story needs to establish itself as Mature and Literary. Good call, there.
Tragic lesbians.
Make sure to compare each character to a specific celebrity so that readers will be able to picture them accurately.
It's not too late for a summer crossover event.
Kill your darlings, then immediately bring them back as vampire sex ghosts.

Ritual is an important part of productivity. Begin each writing session by imagining Robert McKee crying while jerking off.

You'll show them! You'll show them all!

You won't have to do as much research if you replace the city's immigrant population with elves.
If a character has curves, make sure to specify that they are in all the right places. Otherwise, readers will be confused.
That "said" looks awfully lonely. Maybe you should give it an adverb friend. Maybe you should give them ALL adverb friends.

You SHOULD base your protagonist on you. Disguise him by giving him really intense green eyes and an ancestral weapon. You don't have those!
